Egyptians loved confusing subtleties and puns.

Some of the subtleties are purely the result of our ignorance, others are intended:

Subtleties can serve in representing two words with very similar meanings but different (sometimes similar) phonetics.

Postulated dialectic forms:

ğ“†™ â‹ ğ“†‘ â‰  ğ“†‘ snake schnecke

Organic series of sign simplification / rotation / ligatures
ğ“¹ ğ“º ğ“» ğ“¼ ğ“½ ğ“¿ ğ“‚€
ğ“„¹ ğ“„¼ ğ“„º ğ“„»
ğ“‡¢ ğ“‡  ğ“‡¡

Much of the gardiner A,B,C series (man, women, gods) naturally seems subtly related:
ğ“€— ğ“€˜ ğ“€™ ğ“€š ğ“€›

Often these signs carry micro ligatures :
ğ“†µ ğ“†¶ ğ“†´ ğ“‚‹ ğ“Šª ğ“ presumably pointing to diverged but related (dialectic) forms and meanings.
ğ“‡ˆ ğ“‡Š ğ“‡‡ ğ“‡‰
ğ“‚ ğ“‚  ğ“‚Ÿ ğ“‚¦ ğ“‚¥ ğ“‚¡ ğ“‚¢

As in sumerian many similar signs developed through natural evolution and simplification

Others come from different time periods, languages and scribal traditions:

Many look similar in Akkadian but not in their sumerian base form, which can yield insights:
If it looks similar it likely sounds similar.

Some look similar by accident:
ğ“„¤ ğ“„¥
ğ’„‘ â‰  ğ’€¶
ğ’‹« TA â‰  ğ’€´ ÃŒR
ğ’‡· ğ’Œ… LIË¢ â‰  TU
ğ’‹† â‰  ğ’‰ ğ’‹« gunu
ğ’†¦ gunÃ» â‰  ğ’ƒ² gal
ğ’€– AP â‰  ğ’†• DU ğ“š DIU ğ“™ duo Delta â‰ 

Many are components of each other (reverse ligatures)
ğ’„± AR2 â‰  ğ’‹¼ TE/TEÄœ3/TEN

Interestingly the more complicated original form often has a more simple phonetic value and may even be used as alphabetic/syllabic sign dispite its higher complexity, presumably to alleviate ambiguity.
E.g. ğ“  vs ğ“ˆ™ in Darius inscriptions.

Often these carry similar sounds / meanings, despite their temporal distance.

Ablauts, Umlauts

It is possible that some of the ligatures represented Ablauts: change of vowels to change cases or semantics:

ğ“ˆ˜ ğ“ˆ rod road à¤°à¥‹à¤¡ roá¸ river á½Î´ÏŒÏ‚ hodÃ³s (corruption when?)

Ï€-forms versus Âµ-forms

zarÊ¿ zart subtle,tender,green
